pr_title: feat: timestamp support - casting, comparisons and serde

+package io.confluent.ksql.schema.ksql;
+
+import io.confluent.ksql.util.KsqlConstants;
+import io.confluent.ksql.util.timestamp.PartialStringToTimestampParser;
+import java.sql.Timestamp;
+import java.time.ZoneId;
+import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter;
+
+/**
+ * Helpers for working with Sql {@code TIMESTAMP}.
+ */
+public final class SqlTimestamps {
+
+  private SqlTimestamps() {
+  }
+
+  /**
+   * Parse a SQL double from a string.

timeline.bodyText: parse is gonna parse strings with timezones if the string contains +0200 for instance. Isn't this going to cause an issue?
timeline.author: spena

timeline.bodyText: Add a test to parse a time without timezone. Btw, are we supporting this? or what is the behavior we discussed when using timezone values in the a string?
timeline.author: spena

replies.bodyText: The conclusion was to include a conversion function and to not store timezone information. Timezones in strings were not specified in the klip, but I think it makes sense to support it because this is basically the same thing as calling CONVERT_TZ("2017-11-13T23:59:58.999","-0100"), and it is something we already support in some filter expressions.
replies.author: jzaralim

timeline.bodyText: Can PartialStringToTimestampParser be a static field in the class? It will avoid re-creating this object every time we parse a timestamp.
timeline.author: spena

See the License for the + * specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. + */ + +package io.confluent.ksql.schema.ksql; + +import io.confluent.ksql.util.KsqlConstants; +import io.confluent.ksql.util.timestamp.PartialStringToTimestampParser; +import java.sql.Timestamp; +import java.time.ZoneId; +import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter; + +/** + * Helpers for working with Sql {@code TIMESTAMP}. + */ +public final class SqlTimestamps { + + private SqlTimestamps() { + } + + /** + * Parse a SQL double from a string. + * + *

Rejects {@code Infinity} and {@code Nan} as invalid. + * + * @param str the string to parse. + * @return the double value. + */ + public static Timestamp parseTimestamp(final String str) { + return new PartialStringToTimestampParser().parseToTimestamp(str);

timeline.bodyText: Question: why is it removed? I did not understand what this condition does.
timeline.author: spena

replies.bodyText: This function for types that are declared using a construction, such as DECIMAL(4,2). There seems to have been some sort of attempt to include the timestamp type in the beginning of the project, which is why this is here.
replies.author: jzaralim

timeline.bodyText:
Why not passing the long value instead of the Timestamp?
I was going to ask why not storing the Timestamp object instead of the long, but I noticed Timestamp is mutable.
timeline.author: spena

replies.bodyText: The code passes around a Timestamp value. We could intitialize with a long value instead, but the conversion would still have to be made at some other location in the code.
replies.author: jzaralim

timeline.bodyText: Add another test that allows parsing a string timestamp.
timeline.author: spena

timeline.bodyText: All the types have the SqlBaseType. reference. Can we keep that consistent for the timestamp in all the code? (SqlBaseType.TIMESTAMP)
timeline.author: spena

timeline.author: spena

replies.bodyText: connectToSpec is used for checking the values in streams in functional tests. These values are verified against values in a json file and since json files cannot store timestamp objects, comparing the millis is the only way to check timestamp values.
replies.author: jzaralim

timeline.author: spena

timeline.bodyText: Should we use the Timestamp.LOGICAL_NAME instead of hardcoding the name?
timeline.author: spena

timeline.message: update klip to include time zones in date strings
